factoid: Kutúzov’s face suddenly softened.
Tears came into Kutúzov’s eyes.
Kutúzov drew Bagratión toward Kutúzov with left hand.
Kutúzov wore a ring on right hand.
Kutúzov made sign of cross over Bagratión with habitual gesture.
Kutúzov offered puffy cheek.
Kutúzov’s cheek was puffy.
Bagratión kissed Kutúzov on neck.
Kutúzov said “Christ, I cannot believe I am here.”
Kutúzov went toward Kutúzov’s carriage.
Soldiers’ uniforms were in disarray.
Bagratión’s heart thudded in chest.
Sky was dull gray.
Wind blew across grass.
Grass was damp with dew.
Soldiers’ boots were dusty.
Kutúzov and Bolkónski drove for few minutes in silence.
Ground was covered with fallen leaves.
Leaves were scattered across path.
Kutúzov said “If a tenth part of Prince Bagratión’s detachment returns I shall thank God.”
Kutúzov questioned Prince Andrew about details of Prince Andrew’s interview with Emperor.
Kutúzov questioned Prince Andrew about remarks heard at court concerning Krems affair.
Kutúzov questioned Prince Andrew about ladies both knew.
On November 1 Kutúzov received news through spy that Kutúzov’s army was almost hopeless.
If Kutúzov remained at Krems, Napoleon’s army of one‑hundred‑fifty‑thousand would cut Kutúzov off completely and surround Kutúzov’s exhausted army of forty‑thousand.
If Kutúzov remained at Krems, Kutúzov would find himself in Mack’s position at Ulm.
If Kutúzov abandoned road connecting Kutúzov with troops from Russia, Kutúzov would march without road into unknown Bohemian mountains.
If Kutúzov abandoned road connecting Kutúzov with troops from Russia, Kutúzov would defend against superior enemy forces.
If Kutúzov abandoned road connecting Kutúzov with troops from Russia, Kutúzov would abandon hope of junction with Buxhöwden.
If Kutúzov retreated along road from Krems to Olmütz to unite with troops from Russia, Kutúzov risked being forestalled by French who had crossed Vienna bridge.
If Kutúzov retreated along road from Krems to Olmütz to unite with troops from Russia, Kutúzov was encumbered by baggage and transport.
If Kutúzov retreated along road from Krems to Olmütz to unite with troops from Russia, Kutúzov would have to accept battle on march against enemy three times as strong.
If Kutúzov retreated along road from Krems to Olmütz to unite with troops from Russia, enemy would hem Kutúzov in from two sides.
If Kutúzov reached Znaim before French, great hope would exist to save Kutúzov’s army.
If Kutúzov let French forestall Kutúzov at Znaim, Kutúzov’s whole army would be exposed to disgrace such as Ulm.
If Kutúzov let French forestall Kutúzov at Znaim, Kutúzov’s whole army would be exposed to utter destruction.
It was impossible for Kutúzov to forestall French with Kutúzov’s whole army.
The enemy’s position was uncertain.
The enemy’s position was clear.
The enemy’s position was uncertain.
The enemy’s position was clear.
The enemy’s position was uncertain.
The enemy’s position was clear.
Night of news receipt, Kutúzov sent Bagratión’s vanguard, four thousand strong, to right across hills from Krems‑Znaim to Vienna‑Znaim road.
Bagratión was to halt facing Vienna with Znaim to rear.
If Bagratión succeeded in forestalling French, Bagratión was to delay them as long as possible.
Kutúzov took road to Znaim with all transport.
